Introduction
This tutorial is intended to help you write your own classes for use with the toolkit. We assume that you understand the basic concepts of object-oriented programming. If not, we recommend that you read chapter six of Learning Python (Lutz & Ascher).
You will generally be interested in writing two different types of classes: data classes; and processing (or task-oriented) classes. Data classes are used to store information that is relavant to some task. Examples of data classes are Location, Token, and FreqDist. Processing classes define methods that can be used to perform a variety of tasks. Examples of processing classes are WhitespaceTokenizer, UnigramTagger, and ChartParser.
Writing Classes in Python
This section gives a very brief description of Python's class system. If you are already comfortable with writing classes in Python, you can safely skip this section. For more in-depth information on how to use object-oriented programming with Python, please refer to a Python textbook, such as Learning Python (Lutz & Ascher).
Declaring Classes
Python classes are declared with the class keyword. This keyword begins a block, which should contain method definitions. Method definitions have the same form as function definitions.
>>> class SimpleClass: ... def set(self, value): ... self.data = value ... def get(self): ... print self.data
Explicit Qualification
Unlike methods in most object oriented languages, Python methods all take the object being acted on as an explicit argument. This argument is conventionally called self, and is the first argument to any method. Any member variables must be accessed through self. In the above example, the data member variable is accessed as self.data.
This explicit qualification of member variables may seem annoying to programmers who are used to the more conventional implicit qualification. However, it allows you to clearly distinguish member variables from local variables. In fact, making this distinction clear is one of the reasons that many programmers prefer to begin member variables with a prefix (such as "m_").
Constructors
New member variables are created simply by assigning to them. It is an error to read from a member variable before it has been assigned to. To ensure that all member variables are properly initialized, most classes define a constructor. A class's constructor is called whenever a new instance is created. Like all member functions, it recieves the object being acted on as an explicit argument. The class constructor is named __init__, to distinguish it from other methods.
>>> class SimpleClass: ... def __init__(self): ... self.data = 0 ... def set(self, value): ... self.data = value ... def get(self): ... print self.data ... >>> x = SimpleClass()
If the constructor takes additional arguments, then those arguments must be given when creating a new instance:
>>> class SimpleClass: ... def __init__(self, initial_value): ... self.data = initial_value ... def set(self, value): ... self.data = value ... def get(self): ... print self.data ... >>> x = SimpleClass(4)
Inheritance
You can specify that a new class B is a subclass of A with the following syntax:
>>> class B(A): ... def __init__(self): . .
You should also use this syntax to specify that a new class B implements the interface A.
Processing Classes
Processing classes define one or more methods that can be used to process data. Each processing class typically implements some interface, which specifies the behavior for its processing methods. For example, WhitespaceTokenizer is a processing class that implements the TokenizerI interface.
NLTK uses class inheritence to indicate that a class implements an interface. For example, the following code defines a new class implementing the TokenizerI interface:
>>> class SimpleTokenizer(TokenizerI): ... def tokenize(self, str): ... words = str.split() ... return [Token(words[i], Location(i)) ... for i in range(len(words))]
Whenever you define a new processing class that implements an interface, you must provide definitions for every method defined by the interface.
Customization Parameters
Some processing classes have customization parameters. These are values given to the constructor, which determine how the class will process its input. For example, the RETokenizer class takes a single customization parameter: a regular expression, which it uses to determine how it should tokenize texts.
State
Processing classes can be either stateful or stateless. A stateful processing class maintains dynamic information in its member variables, and uses this information while processing input. For example, the UnigramTagger class maintains an internal frequency distribution, which it uses to decide which tag to associate with each word type.
